ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lectures if needed
There was a lecture part in the beginning of class as well as pre recorded videos that we watched.
None
We used virtual seminar-style learning, virtual group discussions, virtual lecturing, and pre-made, pre-recorded videos to watch at home for our homework assignments for each class.
It was a virtual seminar.
Breakout rooms
The class included the seminar and discussion, breakout rooms, and video quizzes in between classes to prepare us for the work ahead.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Applications of math that are useful in everyday life
I learned a lot about how the math we learn in our classes can be applied to everyday situations. The class also introduced me to some new types of math.
I developed basic mathematical skills but were especially able to apply them towards real life.
I learned all forms of math and how they work in the world we live in. I thoroughly enjoyed the class and believe i learned a lot.
applying math concepts to real world ideas. Rates of growth, combinations, permutations, probability etc
We learned a lot of realistic math situations

Honestly, I actually learned a lot about how math works in the real world. The title of this course is no joke; you do actually come out with at least a basic understanding of a lot of topics that are marginally pertinent to your daily life. We started with algebra basics, and then we modeled exponential growth and decay, in terms of money and investments, nuclear explosions, chain reactions. We then worked with probability and solved things like the Monty Hall problem; we talked about lottery tickets, super computers, hackers. We pivoted to modular arithmetic, which was probably the coolest topic we discussed all semester, partially because I'd never seen it before, which was a fun way to calculate birthdays, seasons, random dates. And then we ended with basic statistics and sequences/series to talk about mortgages. Out of all of the topics, probability was the one I feared the most, and I honestly can say that I don't feel so worked up about it anymore. If you're looking for something at least a little practical without making it too difficult, this is the class to take.
I learned how to create a presentation, and I discovered many ways math applies to the real world.
Real world math skills
I learned a wide range of math skills in this class.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths- the videos before class were extremely helpful 
weakness- homework was more difficult than in class worksheets

I liked that the professor started each class with a quiz and then a lesson to explain the content of the quiz. I wish that there were more lessons instead of breakout room work as I would sometimes get confused on some questions. However, this was somewhat made up for as the professor would join each breakout room and ask if we needed help.
I think the course is really effective at teaching the material but student engagement could be improved.
i really only see strengths in this class. It was broken up very well.
Maybe switching up breakout rooms

This class covers a lot of material, which is both a strength and a weakness. I feel like some topics we breezed right through -- in part because the class seemed to pick it up faster, but also because there wasn't enough time to really take a deep dive. A lot of topics we only cursorily covered, and while it's certainly interesting to get a taste of each and every thing we did in fact discuss, perhaps we could've spent more time on particular units, or went more in-depth. But then again, this is not intended to be a deep dive into mathematical processes, so I guess that makes it a strength, too. 

Another strength was my group. After the second class, the group I was in was the group I worked with for the rest of the semester, which was fantastic. However, I'm not sure what my classmates perceptions of their groups were, so I guess group-work can really make or break the quality of the class. The class was also just really well taught, and Rachel is a true delight. Please take classes with her. She's a gem, and will actually walk you through problems and answer your questions. You won't be left in the dark, confused and maddened by numbers and formulas.

The textbook, however, is kind of useless. Only used it for homework assignments. Don't know why it's required if everything is explained in the class anyway.
I felt I learned very well with the breakout rooms and doing worksheets with my class mates.
Not sure
I could not have taken a more helpful math class this semester. I do not know how it could be improved.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Breakout rooms succeeded for the purposes of group work and worksheets
The lessons succeeded. The professor was able to take advantage of the whiteboard in Zoom to show the lessons. I did not find much that count be improved.
The virtual format generally seemed to work, but I wonder if there could be improvements with the testing situations for online exams.
It was all online and everything seemed to work out. I do believe it was a little stressful taking a math test over a computer but besides that it was great.
No threat with virtual

This class operated in a semi-flipped fashion. That means that we watched video(s) -- sometimes one video, sometimes two videos -- prior to the start of a new unit of the material, explaining the topic. The videos were top notch, and I mean that. Rachel clearly put a ton of time and effort into making the videos, and they were brilliantly fashioned with explanations, example problems, and definitions. What followed was really short quiz, which we could retake until getting all of the answers right, which was another plus -- not only did they reinforce the fact that you watched the video, they also wouldn't hurt your grade. The only thing is that when the videos' length approached 7-10 minutes, it felt like it was taking up a lot of my time, as I'd spend about an hour watching and taking notes, making sure I understood the material. 

We also made use of the share screen function often, as well as breakout rooms to facilitate group work. Rachel had a way that she could connect her tablet, I believe, to Zoom, so that she could write in real time and we could solve problems together. The breakout rooms were how we work in groups every class, and the "ask for help" button would send Rachel into the "classroom" to help with problems and answer questions. All of this was very effective, and for the most part, very efficient. 

The only thing I wished had been stressed was having videos on during the intended-to-be interactive lecture/discussion portion at the beginning of class. I had my video on every class without fail, and I understand some people have personal issues with having their video turned on. But it also hindered participation; I felt that often I was of the only people actually participating in class and engaging actively with Rachel's very well-prepared lectures and explanations. I mean, you get out of the class what you put in, but it would've been nice to see more engagement on the part of my peers.
I was very engaged and it did not hinder my learning.
Zoom and breakout rooms worked well
Everything in the course was very instructional and intentional, and I benefitted greatly from the lecture, breakout rooms, and video quizzes.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes if you need a QR requirement and you are not a STEM student

I would recommend this course to another student. The main reason for why is because it allows you to see math in a whole new perspective. Most classes in school/college don't teach the real world applications of the content you learn. With this class, you not only learn math, but also learn how to apply it to the real world.
I would recommend this course. Especially for students who dont plan to do STEM or arent confident in their math skills.
Yes I would. It was taught very well and i was provided a strong learning environment.
Yes, especially one that is not great at math, not too difficult and a student at any math level student can participate
Yes

I would 100% recommend this class to another student, without qualms. I am a math-averse student. I see equations and algebraic symbols and bad memories come flowing back. Rachel Diethorn changed those feelings. If anything, take this class for the brilliance that is Rachel. She not only explains everything, she is helpful and kind. She clearly loves teaching the math, and the topics in this class are actually interesting. You also get an entire page for a cheat sheet on each exam, so there's no need to memorize anything. You can get help with homework problems, classwork problems, you name it -- and Rachel will actually walk you through the problems. I went to office hours and asked to do some additional practice problems, and Rachel sat there with me on Zoom and did them alongside me, making sure I got them correct. I really, really don't like math, but this was one of my most anticipated classes of each week. While not everything in this course is totally practical, some of it is; and even if you don't find yourself using all of the math and the tools that you learned in class after you take the class, you walk away with some pretty cool knowledge. Also, no final exam was a great addition -- and the final project was pretty creative, applying a concept from class to some real-world topic. It's also about the applications in this class.
I would recommend this course to another student. I was very fun and I learned a alot.
Yes, I would. The class is helpful for non-STEM inclined students, and Professor Diethorn is very helpful and patient as a teacher.

extras.title:
MATH 107 01
        Mathematics in the Real World
